tha15:673: "My confidence grewAs I heard the Dhamma, so full of flavor.Dispassion was the Dhamma that was taught,Without any grasping at all."
tha15:674: "There are many pretty thingsIn the circle of this earth;They disturb one’s thoughts, I believe,Beautiful, provoking lust.
tha15:675: Just as a rain cloud would settleThe dust blown up by the wind;So thoughts settle downWhen seen with understanding.
tha15:676: All conditions are impermanent —When this is seen with understanding,One turns away from suffering:This is the path to purity.
tha15:677: All conditions are suffering —When this is seen with understanding,One turns away from suffering:This is the path to purity.
tha15:678: All phenomena are not-self —When this is seen with understanding,One turns away from suffering:This is the path to purity.
tha15:679: The senior monk Koṇḍañña, who was awakenedRight after the Buddha, is keenly energetic.He has abandoned birth and death,And has perfected the spiritual life.
tha15:680: There are floods, snares, and strong posts,And a mountain hard to crack;Snapping the posts and snares,Breaking the mountain so hard to break,Crossing over to the far shore,One practicingjhānais freed from Māra’s bonds.
tha15:681: A haughty and fickle monk,Relying on bad friends,Sinks down in the great flood,Overcome by a wave.
tha15:682: But one who is humble and stable,Controlled, with senses restrained,Wise, with good friends,Would put an end to suffering.
tha15:683: With knobbly knees,Thin, with veins matted on his skin,Eating and drinking in moderation —This person’s spirit is undaunted.
tha15:684: Pestered by gadflies and mosquitoesIn the awesome wilderness;One should mindfully endure,Like an elephant at the head of the battle.
tha15:685: I don’t long for death;I don’t long for life;I await my time,Like a worker waiting for their wages.
tha15:686: I don’t long for death;I don’t long for life;I await my time,Aware and mindful.
tha15:687: I’ve attended on the teacherAnd fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.The heavy burden is laid down,I’ve undone the attachment to being reborn in any state of existence.
tha15:688: I’ve attained the goalFor the sake of which I went forthFrom home life into homelessness —What use do I have for students?"
tha15:689: An person who has become awakened as a human being,Self-tamed, withsamādhi,Following the spiritual path,Delights in peace of mind.
tha15:690: Revered by people,Gone beyond all things,Even the gods revere him;So I’ve heard from the Arahant.
tha15:691: He has transcended all fetters,And escaped from entanglements,Delighting in the renunciation of sensual pleasures,He is liberated like gold from stone.
tha15:692: That elephant outshines all,As the Himālaya outshines other mountains.Of all those named "elephant",He is truly named, and unsurpassed.
tha15:693: I’ll extol the elephant to you,For he does nothing wrong.The elephant’s front two feetAre gentleness and harmlessness.
tha15:694: Mindfulness and awarenessAre the elephant’s other feet.Faith is the great elephant’s trunk,And equanimity is the white tusks.
tha15:695: Mindfulness is his neck, his head is understanding —The investigation and reflection on phenomena —His belly is the sacred hearth of the Dhamma,His tail is seclusion.
tha15:696: Practicingjhāna, delighting in the breath,Serene inside himself.The elephant is serene when walking,The elephant is serene when standing,
tha15:697: The elephant is serene when lying down,And when sitting, the elephant is serene.The elephant is restrained everywhere:This is the accomplishment of the elephant.
tha15:698: He eats blameless things,He doesn’t eat blameworthy things.When he gets food and clothes,He avoids storing them up.
tha15:699: Having cut off all bonds,Fetters large and small,Wherever he goes,He goes without longing
tha15:700: Just as a white lotus,Fragrant and delightful,Is born in water and grows there,But the water does not stick to it;
tha15:701: So the Buddha is born in the world,And lives in the world,But the world does not stick to him,As the water does not stick to the lotus.
tha15:702: A great blazing fireDies down when the fuel runs out;When the coals have gone outIt’s said to be "quenched".
tha15:703: This simile is taught by the discerningTo express the meaning clearly.Great elephants will understandWhat the elephant taught the elephant.
tha15:704: Free of desire, free of hatred,Free of delusion, without defilements,The elephant, abandoning their body,Realisesnibbānawithout defilements.
